etymologies: Middle English: perhaps from Middle Low German, Middle Dutch spiker, related to spoke. The verb dates from the early 17th century

definitions: a thin, pointed piece of metal, wood, or another rigid material.
shortDefinitions: thin, pointed piece of metal

definitions: a large stout nail, especially one used to fasten a rail to a railroad tie.
shortDefinitions: large stout nail

definitions: each of several metal points set into the sole of an athletic shoe to prevent slipping.
shortDefinitions: each of several metal points set into sole of running shoe

definitions: a pair of athletic shoes with metal points set into the sole.
shortDefinitions: pair of running shoes with metal points set into the sole
pointed metal rod standing on base and used for filing paper items such as bills

definitions: a hypodermic needle.
shortDefinitions: hypodermic needle

definitions: a sharp increase in the magnitude or concentration of something
shortDefinitions: sharp increase in magnitude or concentration of something

definitions: a pulse of very short duration in which a rapid increase in voltage is followed by a rapid decrease.
shortDefinitions: pulse of very short duration in which rapid increase in voltage is followed by rapid decrease

definitions: impale on or pierce with a sharp point
shortDefinitions: impale on or pierce with sharp point

definitions: injure (a player) with the spikes on one's shoes.
shortDefinitions: injure player with spikes on one's shoes

definitions: (of a newspaper editor) reject (a story) by or as if by filing it on a spike

examples.text: the editors deemed the article in bad taste and spiked it

shortDefinitions: reject story by or as if by filing it on spike

definitions: stop the progress of (a plan or undertaking); put an end to

examples.text: he doubted they would spike the entire effort over this one negotiation

shortDefinitions: stop progress of

definitions: render (a gun) useless by plugging up the vent with a spike.
shortDefinitions: render gun useless by plugging up vent with spike

definitions: form into or cover with sharp points

examples.text: his hair was matted and spiked with blood

shortDefinitions: form into or cover with sharp points

definitions: take on a sharp, pointed shape
shortDefinitions: take on sharp, pointed shape

definitions: increase and then decrease sharply; reach a peak

examples.text: oil prices would spike and fall again

shortDefinitions: increase and then decrease sharply

definitions: add alcohol or a drug to contaminate (drink or food) surreptitiously

examples.text: she bought me an orange juice and spiked it with vodka

shortDefinitions: add alcohol or drug to contaminate drink or food surreptitiously

definitions: add sharp or pungent flavoring to (food or drink)

examples.text: spike the liquid with lime or lemon juice

shortDefinitions: add sharp or pungent flavouring to

definitions: enrich (a nuclear reactor or its fuel) with a particular isotope

examples.text: the plutonium mixture could be spiked with caesium-137

shortDefinitions: enrich nuclear reactor or its fuel with particular isotope

definitions: (in volleyball) hit (the ball) forcefully from a position near the net so that it moves downward into the opposite court.
shortDefinitions: (in volleyball) hit ball forcefully from position near net so that it moves downward into opposite court

definitions: fling (the ball) forcefully to the ground, typically in celebration of a touchdown.
shortDefinitions: fling ball forcefully to ground

etymologies: late Middle English (denoting an ear of corn): from Latin spica (see spica)

definitions: a flower cluster formed of many flower heads attached directly to a long stem.
shortDefinitions: flower cluster formed of many flower heads attached directly to long stem
